title.narrative: Multi-Sectorial Livelihood Support to Vulnerable Communities in Zimbabwe

description.narrative: At the end of 2020, above average rainfall severely impacted both rural and urban populations in eastern, central and southern parts of Zimbabwe resulting in damages to infrastructure, properties and livelihoods. In addition to natural disasters, the COVID-19 pandemic forced the return of over 170,000 migrants to Zimbabwe, increasing the pressure in communities already highly affected in the Manicaland, Masvingo and Matabeleland South provinces. These areas have witnessed a combination of forced and voluntary returnees coming from neighbouring countries affected by the socio-economic impact of the pandemic. The socioeconomic effects of COVID-19 have disproportionately affected people in vulnerable situations and marginalized communities resulting not only in physical protection risks, limited access to basic services, restricted opportunities for employment and education, social tension, stigmatization but also in significant mental health and psychological and social stress on individuals, families, and communities. Through this project, IOM aims to provide assistance through mental health and psychosocial support to vulnerable households in natural hazard-prone affected areas, support income generating activities for the durable reintegration of returnees, and build the resilience of internally displaced persons, returnees and affected host communities.
